title-group.article-title: Experimental study on the effect of blade angle on regenerative pump performance

abstract.p: The regenerative pump is a kind of turbomachine that is capable of developing a high pressure rise at relatively low flow rates compared to the centrifugal and axial pumps. Although the efficiency of regenerative pumps is much lower than other turbomachines, they have still been widely used in many industrial applications for high heads at low flow rates. There are a few theoretical models to analyze the performance of regenerative pumps, though, the effect of the blade angle has not been included in any analysis model to date. In this study, the influence of the impeller blade angle and its shape on regenerative pump performance has been experimentally investigated. Straight blades with inclined blade angles of 0°, ± 15°, ± 30° and ± 45° were tested. In addition radial chevron impellers with chevron angles of 15°, 30° and 45° were also included in the present experiments. Hence a total of 10 blade configurations were examined. The pressure head, efficiency and the fluid temperature rise were measured at different flow rates and the results were expressed in appropriate non-dimensional coefficients. From the experimental results, it was found that the pressure head and the efficiency strongly depend on the blade angles as well as the blade geometry. Among all blade configurations tested in this study, the chevron blade exhibited the highest head with reasonably good efficiency. The comparative study shows that there is an optimum chevron angle of around 30° that yields the best performance. These experimental data may be used to include the effect of blade angles in the current performance analysis and design models to widen their applicability.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fluid in a regenerative turbomachine passes through the impeller blades as a corkscrew pattern in its peripheral path from inlet to outlet. Such repetitive impeller blading on the fluid allows producing a substantially higher head than any other type of turbomachines with the comparable tip speed. However, typical regenerative turbomachines have an obvious disadvantage of low efficiency, usually less than 50%. Nevertheless, since the regenerative machines exhibit relative compactness, operational stability and low manufacturing cost, they have been widely used when high heads at low flow rates are required in chemical, petroleum, automotive and aerospace fuel pumping, water supply, and shipping industries.

The pumping mechanism of regenerative pumps has been theoretically investigated with mathematical models based on turbulent flow theory1 and momentum exchange theory2 in the mid of 1950. Senoo3 reviewed the two theories and found that they are compatible with each other. Lazo and Hopkins4 and Lutz5 carried out flow visualization experiments using a small thread probe to measure the flow directions in the annular flow passage of the pump and observed the corkscrew flow pattern. Hübel et al.6 conducted a visualization of three-dimensional flow by using the laser light sheet technique in combination with digital image processing. They were able to corroborate that the inner fluid flow pattern follows helix-shaped streamlines. The momentum exchange theory proposed by Wilson et al.2 has been recognized as a good model to intuitively describe the helical motion. Badami,7 Song et al.8 and Yoo et al.9 proposed modified one-dimensional models in order to better correlate internal losses with geometric and hydrodynamic parameters. However, these models need extensive experimental support to determine a number of empirical coefficients in the proposed models. In particular these models do not take account of the influence of blade angle on the performance, and hence they have limited applicability as a design tool.

A few researchers studied the effects of geometrical variables of the regenerative pumps for an optimum design. Main concerns were given to the blade cross-section shape, blade angle and the number of blades.6–10 Sixsmith and Altmann11 studied the regenerative compressor with aerofoil blades. They found that the aerofoil blades produced more pressure rise than any other blade shapes and that the aerofoil blades were shown to guide the fluid to circulate in the annular channel with minimum loss. Although the efficiency was improved compared to the radial plate blade, yet the efficiency remained on the low side, typically around 40%. They showed that large and unexplained losses were present in the corkscrew flow passage. Yamazaki and Tomita12–14 carried out an experimental study of non-radial blades with different side channel areas. They proposed a number of correlation coefficients and empirical equations for head coefficient, torque and efficiency as functions of Reynolds number, blade angle, side channel area and flow coefficient. Hübel et al.6 and Badami7 introduced a chevron impeller that is equipped with angled blades with respect to the axial direction. This chevron blade resulted in improved performance compared with the straight plate blade because of the reduction in the incidence loss at the inlet region of impeller. But they did not provide any information for determination of an optimum chevron angle. Recently, computational fluid dynamic (CFD) methods have been used to investigate the inner flow mechanism in the regenerative machinery.15–17 Computed flow patterns, the pressure and velocity distributions of inner flow, were compared with previous one-dimensional prediction models. Meakhail and Park15 also carried out a CFD study to investigate the flow field in a regenerative turbomachine that are equipped with twisted blades, a combination of chevron inlet blade angle and backwardly inclined angle at the side-blade exit. With a special concern about the circulatory flow at the side blade exit, they analyzed their numerical data and proposed to modify the one-dimensional model based on the momentum exchange theory by Wilson et al.2 However, still there is little information regarding the influence of blade angle on the performance of radial-type impellers.

In this study, in order to investigate the influence of blade angle on the pump performance, an experimental study has been carried out. A regenerative pump system designed by the Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials was used in the present experimental study, and impellers with varying blade shapes were manufactured as depicted in Figures 4 and 5. The symmetrically angled blade in the axial direction as shown in Figures 4 and 5 is called as chevron blade. The forward and chevron blade were machined with three different blade angles of 15°, 30°, and 45°, respectively. Note that the impellers with forward blade can be used as backward bladed impellers by rotating the impellers in reverse direction. The experimental performance data obtained in this study are compared in details to find the influence of the blade angles on the pump performance.

sec.title: Specifics of regenerative pump
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the schematic of a regenerative pump that consists of an impeller (a) with radial blade (b) and a casing (c) where the side channel (d) is machined. There is a stripper block (e) to separate the inlet (f) and outlet (g) ports in the casing. The major geometric specifications of the tested regenerative pump are presented in Table 1 and Figure 2. The test impeller had 45 blades of diameter 170 mm, height 21.2 mm, width 11 mm and thickness 2 mm. As shown in Figure 2, in order to balance the axial thrust on the pump, the impeller was designed as a double suction type. Figure 1.

sec.title: Experiments apparatus
sec.p:
The test rig arrangement is shown in Figure 3. A reservoir was installed in order to store and receive water that is used as a working fluid. The flow rate was adjusted by a flow control valve situated in the return line to the reservoir, and was measured with a turbine flow meter installed upstream of the control valve. The pump was driven by an induction motor that operates at a constant speed of 1000 r/min. The input torque to be used in the pump efficiency calculation was measured by a torque meter installed between the pump and the electric motor, and the angular speed was measured with a proximity sensor. The inlet pressure and the pressure rise were determined by means of capacitive absolute and differential pressure transmitter, respectively, whereas the inlet and outlet temperatures ware measured by K-type thermocouples. A data acquisition system (DAQ) was used to collect the measured data. The pressure was measured with errors less than 1% of the reading and temperatures were monitored with an uncertainty of ±0.05℃. The uncertainty in the flow rate measurement was within ± 0.5%, and the input power was monitored using a torque meter whose accuracy was within 0.3%. The scattered data were evaluated from repeatability tests and sensitivity analyses. Figure 3.
Test rig arrangement.

sec.title: Experiments procedure
sec.p:
As presented in Table 1, a total of 10 impellers were used in the experiments, e.g. radial blade (α = β = 0°), chevron blade (α = 15°, 30°, 45°, with β = 0°), forward blade (β = 15°, 30°, 45°, with α = 0°), and backward blade (β = −15°, −30°, −45°, with α = 0°). The chevron angle, α, and the outlet blade angle, β, are defined as shown in Figure 4 and its sign is determined according to the inclined direction with respect to the rotation direction. Figure 5 shows all of the machined impellers. For every impeller type, we measured the pressure and temperature rise while controlling the flow rate by the flow control valve. The maximum flow rate was monitored according to the system resistance when the flow control valve was fully opened. The experiments for backward blade were conducted by reversing the rotation direction of the forward blade. The main test conditions are summarized in Table 2. Figure 4.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The measured pump performance characteristics are expressed with dimensionless flow coefficient φ and the head coefficient ψ defined by the following equations (1) and (2). Here, Qs is the rigid-body rotational volume displacement rate and is calculated as product of the rigid-body rotation speed Ug = ω ċ rg,o and the flow area in the side channel A0. The hydraulic efficiency η of the regenerative pumps is defined as the ratio between the hydraulic power transferred to the working fluid and the mechanical power P introduced into the system by the impeller. And the power coefficient τ is expressed in equation (3). (1)φ=QQs=QA0Ug (2)ψ=gHUg2 (3)τ=PρA0Ug3 (4)η=ρQgHP=φψτ

Figure 6 shows the measured pump characteristic curves ψ versus φ for radial, forward, backward and chevron blade. For each impeller type, performance curves for three blade angles are compared with the radial blade. In most cases, the maximum flow coefficient in the present experiments was about 0.8. Figure 6.
Pump characteristic curves for: (a) forward; (b) backward; (c) chevron and radial blade.

In the case of forward blade shown in Figure 6(a), the head coefficients decrease convexly with the increasing flow coefficient. Pump heads of all forward blades are lower than those of radial blade for φ < 0.6. At the shut-off condition (φ = 0), the head coefficient of 45° forward blade is 3.0 which is about a half of the radial blade. Generally, increase of the tangential velocity at the exit of the forward blade augments the Euler head. However, since the flow in the side channel is drawn faster by the forward blade than the radial blade, the number of corkscrew circulations between the blade space and flow channel is less than that in the case of radial blade.12 Consequent reduction in the momentum exchange between the flow through the blade space and the flow in the side channel results in decrease of the pressure head.

The overall performance curves of backward type are depicted in Figure 6(b). As can be seen, the head curves decrease concavely with the increasing flow coefficient. It is noted that the concavity of curves increases with the blade angle, which implies that the sensitivity of the head coefficient decreases with the increasing flow coefficient. The dependency of the head coefficient on the blade angle is much similar to that in the impeller of forward blade. The shut-off head coefficient of the 15° backward blade is larger than that of radial blade. And it is found that the maximum flow coefficients for all blade angles decrease by about 9% in comparison to those of the forward blades. It should be noted that the head coefficients of backward blades are higher than those of forward blades for flow coefficients less than about 0.4 at the same absolute blade angle, whereas the converse is true for about φ > 0.4.

Figure 6(c) shows that the performance curves of chevron type with different chevron angles have nearly the same concavity for all range of the flow coefficient: The concavity is evidently larger than any of those for backward blades. In the low flow rate ranges of less than 0.5, the head performances are dramatically improved in comparison to the radial blade. Considering that the chevron blade has an inclined inlet angle to accept smoothly the circulatory inlet flow from the previous chamber, the incidence loss must be evidently smaller than those in both forward and backward blades. Consequently the pressure rise can be higher than both types of blades. Furthermore since the incident loss is proportional to the square of the difference between the tangential velocity of the inlet flow and the rotational speed of the impeller blades at the entrance, such incidence loss difference appears more markedly in the low flow rate range. Here, it is noted that the fluid tangential velocity at the tip is always slower than the blade tip speed and that the difference decreases with the increasing flow rate. In other words, the chevron angle guarantees smoother inlet of the incoming flow. Meanwhile, since the circulatory flow is discharged through the side of blade as well as the tip of the blade,15 the side-blade exit of the chevron blade seems to play a similar role as the forward blade. Consequently, it is inferred that there is more deviation of the relative current at the side-blade exit of the chevron blade than the straight radial blade. Nevertheless, an observation that its pressure head is higher than that of the radial blade implies that the advantage of the smoother inlet of the chevron blade surpasses the disadvantage of the larger deviation loss through its side-blade exit.

The shut-off head coefficients of chevron blade are about twice that of radial blade. And, there is a significant difference in the effect of blade angle on the head coefficient. The head coefficients of both forward and backward blades have strong dependence on the blade angle, whereas the effect of the chevron angle is minimal for the impeller of chevron blade. In addition, it can be seen in Figure 6(c) that, 30° chevron blade angle yields the best performance among the three chevron angles in the whole range of flow rate. The performance of 45° chevron blade is degraded compared to 30° chevron blade, which implies that there should be an optimum chevron angle for the highest head.

Figure 7 represents measured efficiency curves together with the ideal efficiency curve.2 Overall, the efficiency of the radial blade is higher than any other blade types in the whole range of measured flow rates. The best efficient point (BEP) of the radial blade is found at φ = 0.63 with 47.3%. Figure 7.
Comparison of efficiency curves between: (a) forward; (b) backward; (c) chevron and radial blade.

Figure 7(a) shows comparison of the efficiencies between the three cases of the forward blades and the radial blade. Efficiencies are significantly degraded with the blade angle of 45° for all flow rates. The maximum efficiency of the 45° forward blade is only 37.3% at φ = 0.63, which is about 10% lower than that of the radial blade.

From Figure 7(b), it is found that the more the blades tilt backward, the more the efficiency decreases in the whole range of flow rates. As already pointed out (Figure 6(b)), it is observed that the maximum flow coefficient moves to lower side when the inclined blade angle gets larger and the best efficiency decreases.
All efficiency data of chevron blade show a very similar behavior to the radial blade (Figure 7(c)) except the case of α = 45° in φ > 0.65.

Figure 8 is drawn to compare the effects of the blade type on the head coefficient. As can easily be seen, generally the chevron blade impeller shows the highest head coefficient among the three blade type. Also it can be noted that the chevron blade exhibits the highest head at the chevron angle of 30°. At the low flow rate (φ = 0.2), the backward blade has better head performance than the forward blade. However, when the flow coefficient is over 0.5 in which the best efficient points lie, the head performance of the backward blade appears significantly lower than the forward blade. And, in this range of the flow coefficient, the head performance of the backward blade decreases gradually as the blade angle increases. However, it is hard to observe any consistent trend of the head change depending on both the blade angle and the flow coefficient for the case of forward blade. The 15° backward blade shows the best head performance in low flow rate range whereas the 15° forward blade exhibits the best head performance at higher flow rate. Figure 8.
Comparison of head coefficients between impeller types at φ = 0.2, 0.5 and 0.7.

In general, the loss of fluid mechanical energy through the machine is converted into thermal energy by the law of energy conservation, which results in temperature rise of the working fluid. Hence, in order to access the mechanical power loss occurred, the temperature rise was monitored by measuring the temperatures at inlet and outlet ports of the pump with thermocouples.

Figure 9 shows the experimental data of temperature rise in the radial blade, 30° forward, backward, and chevron blades. Since the capacity of the regenerative pump used in this study is small and the specific heat of water is relatively large, the amount of temperature rise seems to be insignificant. However, it must be significantly large for high power units. In general, as the flow rate decreases near the shut-off condition, the efficiency is degraded fast, and consequently the magnitude of the temperature rise increases fast. In particular, there is a considerable temperature rise in the 30° chevron blade than any other impeller types when the flow coefficient is 0.1. Figure 9.
Comparison of temperature rise between radial and other impeller types of β = ±30° (forward/backward), α = 30° (chevron).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, an experimental study has been carried out to investigate the effect of the blade angle on the regenerative pump performance. Straight blades with inclined blade angles of 0°, ± 15°, ± 30° and ± 45° were tested. In addition radial chevron impellers with chevron angles of 15°, 30° and 45° were also included in the present experiments. Hence a total of ten blade configurations were examined. The pressure head, efficiency and the fluid temperature rise were measured for a wide range of flow rates and they are expressed in appropriate non-dimensional coefficients. Their results were compared and analyzed in detail. Analysis on the measured data made it possible to better understand the effects of the blade angle on the pump performance. The following conclusions can be drawn from this study.

Pressure head and the efficiency depend strongly on the blade angles as well as the blade geometry. The head performances of the forward and backward blades are found to decrease as the inclined blade angle increases. The radial blade exhibits higher head than the forward and backward blades with the inclined angle of 30° and 45° tested herein. The backward blade with the inclined angle of 15° shows higher head in the low flow rate range (φ < 0.3), but at larger flow rate (φ > 0.6) the forward blade yields better head performance than the radial blade. In the case of chevron blade, compared to the radial blade, the pressure head increases markedly as the flow coefficient decreases in φ < 0.5 for all chevron angles. Among all blade configurations tested in this study, the chevron blade exhibited the highest head at the same flow rate.

The radial blade and the chevron blade show comparable efficiency to each other. It is higher than those of both the forward and backward blades with any blade angle. The efficiencies of the forward and the backward blades decrease with increasing blade angle. Comparison among the chevron blades reveals that there is an optimum chevron angle of around 30° that yields the highest head for all flow rates. The best efficiency was about 47% at φ = 0.63. Although the pressure and the efficiency strongly depend on the blade angles and blade configuration as has been confirmed in this study, presently practical models are not available for design and analysis of regenerative pumps that properly take account of the influence of the blade angle on the performance so far. These experimental data may be used to include the effect of blade angles to widen the applicability of the current performance analysis and design models.
